A new message from FMS Superintendent Dr. Eugene Schmidt can be found at this link:
https://district.fms.k12.nm.us/return_to_learn_2020/superintendent_messages

Tonight's message includes some very disappointing and abrupt news. Today the district learned that our School Reentry Plan, which must be approved in its entirety by NMPED, included a component that no longer complied with new guidelines set forth by NMPED. As such, without significant modifications, our plan to return students to classrooms would not be granted approval and could not move forward. After learning this, Dr. Schmidt has announced that all FMS students will continue with virtual learning from home until at least the end of the first quarter, October 9, 2020.

This news is both unexpected and deflating for many of us. All parents, guardians and community members are encouraged to read the message in its entirety at the links above. More communication from the district and from your schools will be forthcoming.

A reminder for staff, students and families and the community: self-isolation and social distancing is an important practice for public health but can be hard on emotional health. During these summer months when children are less connected to school staff and their peers, there are still resources for anyone who might be in distress or in need of support.

The National Suicide Prevention Lifeline can be reached at 1-800-273-8255 or at this link: https://suicidepreventionlifeline.org

The New Mexico Crisis and and Access Line can be reached at 1-855-NMCRISIS (662-7474) or at this link: https://www.nmcrisisline.com/

The state of New Mexico also recently launched NMConnect, a new phone app that provides free 24-hour crisis and non-crisis support and access to behavioral health professionals who can text or talk via phone with individuals needing a listening ear or referrals to longer-term support. The app links users to the New Mexico Crisis Access Line (NMCAL), which provides safety net services statewide. The NMConnect app, available now for iPhone and Android phones.

From the Superintendent - Reflect back to the beginning of the school. Much of the talk and early buzz for the year was on the importance High Reliabilty Schools with a special emphasis on designing and implementing frameworks that lead to safe, supportive and collaborative cultures. HRS frameworks are guided by the educational research of nationally recognized school leader Dr. Robert Marzano. Throughout this past school year, our principals and their staffs engaged in the HRS work. Now, fast forward to today when Dr. Phil Warrick (pictured) from Marzano Resources met virtually with my Central Office team to announce that all nineteen Farmington schools will be awarded Level I status. This is an amazing and wonderful bit of news considering the rigorous process needed for certification. As such, I thank all Farmington educators for caring for students and for embracing learning strategies that lead to higher achievement.
#risingtoexcellenceineverypursuit

The team calendars visit to schools throughout the year as a quick snapshot way of gathering perception data through interviews with students, parents and staff. In addition the team visits classrooms to observe interactions of teachers and students as a key indicator of the learning cycle. Data collected is reviewed and shared with school principals. Our Project SEARCH students served lunch to Central Office staff who ordered and purchased the lunches earlier this week. The skill-building project required the students to take the orders, stay within budget, clean, chop, slice and dice produce, and serve the food to 49 hungry customers.

One Project SEARCH intern said her favorite part was, "helping people and getting food for them to get back to work."

Our Project SEARCH students served lunch to Central Office staff who ordered and purchased the lunches earlier this week. The skill-building project required the students to take the orders, stay within budget, clean, chop, slice and dice produce, and serve the food to 49 hungry customers.

One Project SEARCH intern said her favorite part was, "helping people and getting food for them to get back to work."

Project SEARCH is an internship program for students with disabilities that prepares them for jobs. Interns are high school graduates who spend one year learning valuable employability skills within departments of the City of Farmington and Farmington Municipal Schools.

post_text: While students enjoy a day off, FMS teachers are hard at work during our first “Data Day” of the year. At McCormick, second and third grade teachers combined to create a cohort of nine teachers analyzing student achievement of the first quarter. This unique combination provides more teachers to provide learning assistance (often called interventions) to students who have common struggles. Students who did not reach their first quarter learning goals will begin receiving interventions tomorrow! This meeting allowed for the teachers to group their students for the most targeted interventions possible and optimized learning. Collaboration among grade levels is not always easy but becomes a possibility on professional development days like today. FMS Director of School Improvement, Data and Assessment Nate Pierantoni and McCormick Principal Lyn White visited the meeting and commended McCormick's efforts!

Farmington Municipal Schools would like to take this time to make you aware of an unfortunate incident that occurred at Mesa View Middle School involving a student and a former School Resource Officer (SRO). Out of respect for student privacy, and to comply with student privacy laws, FMS will not speak publicly about the details of this incident. We would like to share with you the steps being taking to avoid a recurrence.

The SRO involved in this incident is no longer placed at any school in our district. Farmington Municipal Schools administration is reviewing this incident with the intent of putting into place procedures and practices to prevent another instance like this.

Rising to Excellence in Every Pursuit includes making school a safe environment for our children. FMS staff is committed to continuing its efforts in that endeavor.
